A claim that antifa members disguised as supporters of President Donald Trump helped ransack the U.S. Capitol building on Wednesday was reported hours after the melee by conservative-leaning news outlet The Washington Times.
A mob of violent Trump supporters swarmed the Capitol, interrupting a joint session of Congress to certify the 2020 election results, USA TODAY reported.
Facial recognition software purportedly identified antifa members among the rioters.

"A retired military officer told The Washington Times that the firm XRVision used its software to do facial recognition of protesters and matched two Philadelphia Antifa members to two men inside the Senate," that news organization reported on Wednesday evening. The military officer is not identified in the article.

XRVision has denied claims that images taken by its software were made available publicly. The article was removed Thursday from the Washington Times' site, but is still available in an archived version.

Before it was retracted, Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., cited the Washington Times article on the floor of the House of Representatives, saying “some of the people who breached the Capitol today were not Trump supporters. They were masquerading as Trump supporters and in fact, were members of the violent terrorist group antifa,” according to The Washington Post.
Gaetz has been an ally for Trump in Congress, according to USA TODAY.

The article was widely shared on social media – including by Gaetz and Virginia Republican gubernatorial candidate and state Sen. Amanda Chase – according to a search in CrowdTangle, a social monitoring and search platform owned by Facebook.
Social media users further spread the claim that facial recognition identified antifa members either in text posts or by sharing a screenshot of the story's headline.
When asked for comment, The Washington Times pointed to an updated version of the story with a correction.

Antifa, a short-hand term for anti-facists, is a decentralized protest movement against white supremacists, authoritarianism and the far-right wing, including some Trump supporters, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Members of the movement attend protests and target right-wing extremists online.
Fact check:Joe Biden has condemned protest-related violence from the left and the right
Images of the facial recognition match between the Philadelphia antifa members and two rioters in the Senate chamber were shared with The Washington Times, the paper said in the now-retracted report.

One person was identified by tattoos marking him a "Stalinist sympathizer." Another who "shows up at climate and Black Lives Matter protests in the West" has no proven association with the movement but was matched against existing photographs, according to the story.

XRVision is a New York-based "computer vision startup" founded in 2015, according to its LinkedIn page. The firm provides wearable video analytics and facial recognition devices to government customers. Posts to the company's LinkedIn page reflect negative sentiments against Hunter Biden, son of President-elect Joe Biden.
An attorney representing XRVision took issue with The Washington Times' reporting on Thursday.

“Our attorney is in contact with the Washington Times and has instructed them to ‘Cease and Desist’ from any claims regarding sourcing of XRVision analytics, to retract the current claims, and publish an apology,” according to a statement provided to BuzzFeed News.
USA TODAY also has reached out to XRVision for comment.

The XRVision attorney told BuzzFeed that two members of neo-Nazi organizations and a QAnon supporter – not members of antifa – were among the rioters identified. Claims that a "retired military officer" shared images with The Washington Times were also false.

“XRVision didn’t generate any composites or detection imagery for the Washington Times nor for a ‘retired military officer’ and did not authorize them to make any such representations,” the attorney stated, according to BuzzFeed.
Image analysis performed by the company was "distributed to a handful of individuals for their private consumption and not for publication," the attorney stated.
The claims made in The Washington Times article appeared to be the "genesis" of unsupported claims that antifa was involved in the attack on the Capitol, according to the Post.

We rate this claim FALSE, based on our research. Members of antifa were not identified among rioters at the U.S. Capitol by a facial recognition company, as claimed in a now-retracted story by The Washington Times. Facial recognition technology firm XRVision publicly refuted the story and demanded a retraction and an apology.
